If I could give this place 6 or 7 stars, I would. With Airbnb filled to the rafters with perfectly acceptable but soulless accommodation, this is throw back to the platform's early days.
Elizabeth's house backs on to the Rock River, and it's off the main road so it's wonderfully secluded. Outside the main things we heard were cicadas and the river. It's so relaxing.
Inside, the house has been tastefully renovated and feels lived in. The kitchen is stocked with almost every item imaginable, the cookware is top grade, and there are plenty of condiments and spices to make tasty meals. (Side hint: get some local corn, it's crazy sweet and delicious.)
The couch, and beds are all very comfortable. And although we only spent a few nights here, we felt fully refreshed.
There's plenty to do at house too with canoes, a zip line, fishing gear, plenty of kids' toys, and board games.
Internet is available, but it's slow, which was great for our needs, but not if you want to work remotely.

A nice house with many places to entertain inside and out. Plenty of beds, linens, pillows, an air mattress.
One bedroom with 3 beds has a small window A/C and there's larger window unit in the living room. It was over 100F outside when we arrived so it took a little time to cool. The bar and pool table rooms in the basement stayed cool though without A/C. I would bring fans for the other bedrooms if it's going to be over 90F but we were outside 90% of our time thanks to the kayaks, hot tub, fire pit, sauna, paddle boat, grill, smoker, fishing, etc.
Bring your own tupperware, Ziploc bags, and paper towels but otherwise the kitchen is well-stocked.
For kayaking, plan to walk back from the nearby boat launch if you leave the cove because if it's rained recently, you won't be able to paddle against the current to come back.
An overall great weekend with 8 of us, each in our own bed, which is hard to find!

The location of this charming older home is perfect for peace, quiet, and a bit of history. Grand Detour has several historic houses and the number of large trees and the river just blocks away add to the ambience. The home's property is large and just blocks away from the John Deere museum. We loved walking the streets during our fall visit.
The downstairs bed was very comfortable and there were plenty of towels and blankets. The Wi-Fi worked very well during our stay and we didn't miss having cable T.V. since there was plenty to do during our visit.
Hubby and I live in a 150-year old home so we're used to the quirks of an older home. Erin's place has gorgeous wood floors downstairs with large windows throughout. The home could use a bit of maintenance. The exterior needs to be painted and the concrete at the bottom of the back steps is eroded and could prove to be dangerous for older folks or small children.
There are several parks in the area for hiking and exploring. Dixon is just a 5-minute drive and has the best coffee at Coffee Crush. Somkit, the Thai restaurant, was also very good and served the best sangria I've ever had. Hazel's in Oregon is also great for coffee and sandwiches. We also enjoyed dinner at the White Pines Lodge and had a seat right next to the fireplace.
I would stay here again. I'm a writer and this quiet retreat is perfect for a writer's retreat.

Erin's house isn't perfect, but it is perfectly charming. If you are looking for a quiet getaway in a town that time forgot, Erin's place is it. We were looking for a place with good hiking and biking close to Chicago. We found that and more in Grand Detour.
My husband and I loved Erin's little farmhouse. First of all, Erin was very responsive to our needs. She and her neighbor Jeff are great hosts. There is a huge yard for the dogs to run in. The bed is very comfy, kitchen well stocked, and bathroom very clean. Nighttime in Grand Detour is silent - we slept like babies.
The town of Grand Detour was a huge surprise. It is tucked in a bend of the Rock River - you only had to walk a couple of blocks in either direction and you would be at the river's banks. It is home to John Deere's original house which is open to the public free of charge. It is also full of well preserved mid-19th-century homes which made for nice scenery on our evening strolls.
Nearby are the Nachusa Grasslands which is home to a wild buffalo herd - bring binoculars! There are numerous state parks for hiking, and the rolling country roads are perfect for long bike rides.
Erin's little farmhouse in Grand Detour was the perfect base for our explorations.
